description.text:
This is a Playset designed to use MLP Blind Bag figurines. It take about 5.5 hours to print using a rift at 10% infill. This was designed in 123D & Inventor Fusion 2013 and was printable on a Replicators. It has been broken into several part to be able to be printed on most any printer (should fit on a Cupcake except for the trees).  
This Playset is the Cider Stand from The Super Speedy Cider Squeezy 6000. I am still finishing up a few details before I can call it complete.  
My Little Pony is the copyright of Hasbro.  
NOTE: I have uploaded the correct Tree 2 and Tree 3 STLs, Please download the 'Fix' versions.

Print one each of the following:

  • Sign

  • Stand

  • Pump

  • Bit Box

  • Fence Backs
    • Print two of each of the following:

  • Apple Flag

  • Fence
    • And as many as you want of the following:

  • Mug

  • Barrel

  • Tree (Parts 1, 2, and 3)

  • Apple Bucket
    • To Build:

  • Print Parts

  • Place (and glue if you want to) the 'pump' in the small hole on the top of the 'Stand'.

  • Place (and glue if you want to) the 'sign' on top of the two columns of the 'Stand'.

  • Glue the 'Apple flag' on top of the 'Sign' above the two columns of the Stand.

  • Glue the 'Fence Back' on back of the 'Fence' To help it stand up.

  • Enjoy

This is was printed directly from the STL made by Frederik Vollbrecht at https://grabcad.com/library/cactuar. The rendering is his as well. It was made as a Christmas gift, a keychain charm. Unfortunately, I did not snag a photo of the final print before we gave it away. This is an in-build pic at normal quality.

The picture is of a "Normal" quality Ultimaker print.  For both prints we used green filament, no painting necessary.  Support everywhere was used to print as a single unit, but it was removed cleanly with a dremel.  The final print was done at 20 mm/s with 0.06mm thickness.  
The STIL file this is based on has many sharp edges to it.  They may render smoothly but this results in the "textured" look of the main body.  We found that fine for a cactus, so left that as is.  
The model is also hollow with holes for the eyes and mouth.  Cura automatically added support structure through the center and this was not an issue.  I also used all the "fix horrible" settings.  While not necessary, this ensured a strong part with more structure.

print_settings.Notes:: Two shells are enough, but you can use three if you want added strength.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Are you tired of throwing away empty filament spools? This project allows you to re-purpose them instead of recycling. It is designed for the Inland filament spools from Micro Center.

A goal of my project was to not only create boxes that fit in the spools, but to make a storage system that is stackable and portable. I also wanted to make drilling the holes for the hinges easy and repeatable.

The files contained here are:
1) 'Reel Box' - you will need four of these per spool.
2) 'Joiners' - two parts, one for the top of the hole in one reel and the bottom of the hole in the other.
3) 'Handle' - two parts, an adapter and the handle.
4) 'Drilling Guide' - assures holes are located where they belong.

There is at least one other project of this type on Thingiverse ("Spool drawer organizer" by Tanatof). I only discovered it a few days ago. Hence, my project is not a copy of that one, but I am happy to see that we have some similar features. Props to Tanatof for a great, attractive design.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Two shells are enough, but you can use three if you want added strength.

Hinges are #8 x 2.5 Drill bit is 5/32 Assembly:

The first step is to make a mark on the both edges of the spool to indicate where the first hole on each side will be drilled. Use a square or a suitable square object to make sure both marks are aligned with each other.

Place the Drilling Guide over the reel with the raised 'shoulder' inserted in the center hole. Align the guide to the mark (as pictured), then slowly start drilling. I emphasize slowly because you don't want the drill bit to 'walk'. After the first hole is drilled, simply rotate the Drilling Guide 90 degrees so the pin of the Drilling Guide is over the newly created hole. Repeat for all four holes. Then flip the reel over and repeat, but remember to carefully align the first hole with the mark you made.

Each hinge will require a #8 x 2.5" threaded rod, available at most hardware stores. Use a 5/32" acorn nut to simplify driving the threaded rod through the hole in the box. Take care to keep the rod square with the box as you begin driving it into the hole. Since it is a snug fit, drive it in slowly so you don't create too much heat. When the acorn nut bottoms out to the box, remove it and use a pliers to turn the screw in the remaining couple turns by hand until there is an even amount protruding for both ends.

Fit the protruding threaded rod ends into the new holes in the spool. Repeat for all four boxes. Voila! You have just re-purposed your spool to store small items.

The parts for the Joiners and Handles are quite simple to figure out. You will discover that the Joiners fit very tightly on the inner lip of the spool hole and must be pressed in with some force. That is by design to keep them from falling out, simplifying the task of stacking the spindles together. Use the male threaded Joiner on the top of the lower spindle so the threads go up. The Handle parts thread onto those exposed threads.

title: xyzprinting AIO y  axis cable chain

description.text:
this is for the aio only the way that xyz has wired the y axis harness leaves no room for flex as such there is a horrabel bind on the wires breaking them from inside the sheath right at the point that they placed the tie downs if this has happened then after you have re spliced the wires and repaired the harness this fix will allow your fix to stay fixed

to gain length in the wires for a proper flex move the wire harness from the top of the y motor to the bottom

the plug to the x motor will just unplug but the zero sensor is glued into the housing and you can not just disconnect the plug because of the way that they put the thing together you can either cut a square out of the cover to give you room to remove the plug or what i had to do is cut all 3 wires and re splice them after moving the cable down

the chain is like my other chain 1 in 1 out ect ect so no chain locks and no nead to remove plug ends

title: TDC for TM Mk23 Socom
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NOTE This product is designed for an advanced user and requires assembly by the form of tapping your own thread with a metric M4 tap. And using a grub screw for adjustment and pressure on the Nub. If this is not possible there is commercial TDC mods for the MK23 that might be more appropriate for you.

The design is still kinda experimental, It is being tested in multiple TM MK23 pistols, with different barrel configurations, trying to find the best results.

It has been tested in a stock MK23 Socom with no modification, Stock TM bucking and nub, original adjuster set to off. With good results. Far surpassing the original design that does not provide enough movement downwards on the hop.

I have also been using this with a R Hoped Maple Leaf Barrel with great results. adjustment is alot finer as normal with R-Hop systems.

The design for this product is also available on shapeways, for those without their own 3D printers. I'd appreciate any donations to help expand my tools available to continue my airsoft teching journey.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Notes:

I printed it like a bridge. With support. This gave the top surface the cleanest look. You may need to sand the inside edges to get it to slide on nicely. As well as drilling out the mounting holes for the perfect fit.

Cleaning

I always lightly sanded off any seams and left over support material from the inside to give a smoothe fit.

Also drilling out the mounting holes can help get the perfect fit

Tapping

The design is made to put a m3 tap right for the top hole for an adjustment screw. This works well if a maple leaf I key is used.

Otherwise drill out to 3.3mm and use a m4 tap and apply pressure to the entire original hop arm assembly.

Install

Remove slide.
Remove barrel
Set Hop Completely off. Or disassemble and remove adjustment wheel
Unclip The original cover
Clip On TDC
Reassemble
Shoot Stuff

Then your maximum is determined by how much you want exposed either for tool less adjustment or for your own holster, that may be tighter like a Warrior systems or have no restrictions like the Double Tap Designs one. description.text:
Steering Wheel Spinner Knob, also know as a "suicide knob" of "necker knob". I don't really recommend really using this during driving, since the fusion deposition modeling (filament 3D printing) the layers are prone to delamination and it could break during a crucial time during driving. Also, using this drivice for driving may be against some city ordinances.

The bushing is printed in NinjaFlex and the rest is in PLA at 50% infill.

The stl files may need to be reoriented for better printing. You shouldn't need any supports.

Assembly shown here.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FxxUHgYH9GQ&feature=youtu.be

This is designed to print in two parts, to hopefully minimize clean-up and make it easier to fit on a print bed. It also has screw holes, rather than modeled screws - I actually modeled some on, but based on past experiences it's pretty easy to get hardware and just attach it with stuff like this. These holes are sized for M4 screws.Separates into two parts for printing, with holes for alignment pins (1.5mm diameter, I use brass rod from a hobby store) to make attaching the parts together easier.

This was scaled against a pilot model I exported from Titanfall and set to 6'2" tall, so I have a good feeling I got the dimensions right. Until I have had a chance to print it, though, it's going to be marked as a W.I.P.

The shoulder pads are not identical, and are not shaped exactly the same. The pilot's left shoulder wraps around some sort of padded armor, so it is not as curved on the back. Right shoulder also has a bit more of a taper towards the bottom. There also seems to be a dent or other impact mark on the right shoulder pad, which I modeled into the part itself.

title: Dual or single DPS-1200FB power supply mount

description.text:
I designed this mount to hold a pair of DPS-1200FB power supplies to upgrade my Rostock max V2 for 24V heated bed easily. They (should) mount directly up to the stock bolt pattern using the same m4 screws if your unit has the non-ATX 12V 350W supply; I've placed m4 inserts in the same 50x150mm pattern. It sits entirely within the footprint of the existing power supply in my unit, and since it is a pair of 12V supplies I can tap off the 12V rail for most of the electronics and use them in series for a 24V rail to run the bed and hot end, etc. These power supplies are great ,reliable, small, and powerful units, rated for 900W (12V 75A) each when powered at 110VAC 60Hz or 1200W (12V 100A) when run from 220VAC.

The supplies install using the latch mechanism just like they would in the server they're intended for, so they are easy to remove and replace if necessary. Just unplug wires, press the lever, and slide out. There is a slot for a large zip tie to hold the output ends more securely to the bracket if necessary.

Needs 4 M4 4.7mm deep thermoplastic inserts from McMaster, which are installed downwards from the top to help prevent them pulling out of the part. The upper power supply in the series will require some modification to separate the output DC return from earth ground. The housing remains grounded so safety isn't compromised, but of course you perform these modifications and use this mount entirely at your own risk.

That said, its very common to do this mod to use these supplies for RC plane/car/copter battery charging, so there are some good walkthroughs online. I've yet to hear of any issues with running them in series this way on the forums. I've included clearance for the screw heads on the floating unit if they protrude at all (mine do).

I haven't actually installed this yet, so I dont know for certain that it wont require some adjustment; I'll update the parts and descriptions if they do!

I was originally going to use two of the single PSU cases, but then realized its a lot more efficient to make a dual mount that holds them by the ends. I've posted it anyway in case anyone finds it useful!

UPDATE: edited the rear portion for the screw head relief cutouts. I was also thinking baout making this into a n actual rostock max side panel so the PSU fans vent the hot air directly to the outside. I could use an external Y cable to power both, and nonnect the power switch only to their enable/disable pin for turning the whole unit on and off. That would be cleaner and would probably free up some interior volume for the SSR and the current power panel could have a large fan in place of the current IEC inlet.

title: Monoprice MP Select Mini 40mm Fan Duct Shroud Improved
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE
Version 2 out now
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2166473

I used the lower part cooling section from FDM_Guru's 40mm Fan Duct then created the rest from a design I was previously working on.
The goal was to put more air directly onto the part and divide the airflow close to 50/50 between the heat break and part.
The first 40mm fan I purchased was a silent model with not much more airflow over stock and I found FDM_Guru's version was pushing less air onto the part causing more stringing in my prints over the stock duct so I designed this duct to be functionally similar to the stock unit while fitting a 40mm fan.
You don't need any supports to print this part. The clip holders have been beefed up on the bottom & back to make up for the lack of clipping on the top.
The top of the unit will rest on the heat break to prevent the duct from lowering into your prints.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

author: ryanryan1234

description.text: A full writeup with links is at my blog: http://eclecti.cc/hardware/blinded-by-the-light-diy-retinal-projection After grabbing a couple of Microvision SHOWWX laser picoprojectors when they went up on Woot a few months back, I started looking for ways to use them. Microvision started out of a project at the University of Washington HITLab in 1994 to develop laser based virtual retinal displays. That is, a display that projects an image directly onto the userâ€™s retina. This allows for a potentially very compact see through display that is only visible by the user. The system they developed reflected lasers off of a mechanical resonant scanner to deflect them vertically and horizontally, placing pixels at the right locations to form an image. The lasers were modulated to vary the brightness of the pixels. The SHOWWX is essentially this setup after 15 years of development to make it inexpensive and miniaturize it to pocket size. The rest of the retinal display system was a set of optics designed to reduce the scanned image down to a point at the userâ€™s pupil. I thought I would try to shrink and cheapen that part of it as well. The setup I built is basically what Michael Tidwell describes in his Virtual Retinal Displays thesis. The projected image passes through a beamsplitter where some of the light is reflected away, reflects off of a spherical concave mirror to reduce back down to a point, and hits the other side of the beamsplitter, where some of the light passes through and the rest is reflected to the userâ€™s pupil along with light passing through the splitter from the outside world. For the sake of cost savings, all of my mirrors are from the bargain bin of Anchor Optics. The key to the project is picking the right size and focal length of the spherical mirror. The larger setup in the picture uses a 57mm focal length mirror, which results in a fairly large rig with the laser scanner sitting at twice the focal length (the center of curvature) away from the mirror. The smaller setup has a focal length around 27mm, which results in an image that is too close to focus on unless I take my contact lenses out. Aside from my inability to find properly shaped mirrors, the big weakness of this rig is the size of the exit pupil. The exit pupil is basically the useful size of the image leaving the system. In this case, it is the width of the point that hits the userâ€™s pupil. If the point is too small, eye movement will cause eye pupil to miss the image entirely. For this system, the exit pupil is only around 1.5 mm wide, which makes it completely impractical to use head mounted or really, any other way. I paused work on this project a few months ago with the intention of coming back to it when I could think of a way around this. With usable see through consumer head mounted displays just around the bend though, I figured it was time to abandon the project and publish the mistakes Iâ€™ve made in case it helps anyone else.

If you donâ€™t significantly reduce the intensity of light coming from the projector, you will damage your eyes, possibly permanently. The HITLab system had a maximum laser power output of around 2 Î¼W. The SHOWWX has a maximum of 200mW, which is 100,000x as much! Some folks at the HITLab published a paper on retinal display safety and determined that the maximum permissible exposure from a long term laser display source is around 150 Î¼W, so I needed to reduce the power by at least 10,000x to have a reasonable safety margin. I glued a ND1024 neutral density filter over the exit of the projector, which reduces the output to 0.1%. Additionally, the beamsplitter I picked reflects away 10% of the light after it exits the projector, and 90% of what bounces off of the concave mirror. Between the ND filter, the beamsplitter, and setting the projector to its lowest brightness setting, the system should be safe to use. The STL file and a fairly ugly parametric OpenSCAD file for the 3D printed rig to hold it all together are uploaded here.

author: UnmotivatedGene

description.text: Two version of the Kentucky Wildcats coaster.

At first my Rostock Max V2 was not reliable and successful prints at higher extrusion speeds were not attainable. Thought it was nozzle plugging but actually the original idler bearing riding off the filament, (prone on low diameters <1.69). After replacing half of the EZstruder to restrict filament play and upgrade the idler bearing I now have reliability and higher extrusion speed. Other benefits over the OEM part: flexible filament, switch colors during print.
Fitting a large skate bearing where a bearing half its size resided was a challenge. Used a couple of jewelers files to remove interference. With a curved file I removed a tiny part of the remaining EZstruder where the skate bearing rubbed.
Parts needed: x1 608Z skate bearing and x2 25mm M3 hex head bolts to mount the Buffstruder. The spring for the upgrade can be sourced from the discarded half. Designed for MK7 gear.
The bearing arms are mirrored so they don't snap together. There is a spot to hold them together using a piece of 1.75 filament. I found that the melted, then hardened, 2 mm diameter slugs pulled from the hot end when changing filament is optimal.

author: Schorhr

description.text:
I first have to say that I love the model from the original designer. He did a fantastic job doing most of the leg work for this model.

I printed it out and ran into some issues.
Because of the complex nature of 3D printing, I believe that nothing should have supports. It shows a lack of creativity in design. (Unless you are going for realism)

I also found that the model lacked the ergonomics that a prop of this design might have.

So I hopped onto Fusion 360 and did my best to make the model printable without supports and to make it more printable for machines of a lower quality... and I had fun making a cool looking render. :)

I did this with a few extrusions and a ton of fillets.

UPDATE 2/22/17

After a trial print, there was not enough tolerance between the barrel and trigger assembly, no rear sight, and no trigger

New fixed .stl files are added.

Plus a new render!

WARNING
THIS IS A NON-FUNCTIONING PROP
NOT FOR USE AS A WEAPON

Assembly Tips

This prop takes 3 M3 (1x ~5 mm and 2x 10 mm) screws to assemble and a bit of hot glue or any bonding material for the grip panels

Two M3 screws help mate the trigger housing to the grip and one M3 screw helps mate the trigger to the trigger housing (optional, hot glue works too)

title: LCD 12864 RepRap Discount Anet A8 Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This allows to fully use the cheap LCD12864 from RepRap Discount as an alternative display for your Anet A8 printer.

For this to work you need to use the SkyNet3D port of the Marlin firmware. You can get this from the Facebook Support Page as package together with guides on how to setup sensors and stuff. You may also just get the current development version from the GitHub repository.

Disclaimer This "Thing" is meant for people which basically need the raw information and can handle the remaining stuff themselves. You are using this informations on your own risk. I am not responsible if your hardware breaks or your printer suddenly makes or is toast. If you need help with SkyNet3D or Marlin refer to original support!

I added some images of my working prototype. They are just to proof that it works and give an overview on how it was done. I may add more informations later on.

Until now there was only supported for the Anet A6 LCD12864 version of the full graphics display available in SkyNet3D. Afaik this is the first guide to get the LCD 12864 RepRap Discount Display controller working with the original Anet A8 board.

Creating an adapter wiring is actually easy!

Using patch cables:

A quick and easy way for people which don't want to cut their ribbon cables is to use ten breadboard "patch cables" (female to male) and stick the female part into the RepRap Connectors and the male part into the connectors of the cables. Garry did this here and I think that is a really good idea and very easy to do if you have some of those available.

Soldering:

Another way to do this is cutting the two ribbon 10 wire cables which usually come with the RepRap Discount Display. Splicing them and reconnect them using the information provided below. I was soldering them to some connectors which also keeps the cable spread out nicely."

Free Connection:

There is a free pin with this setup. I use it for my 3D-Touch sensor setup. I made the adapter so that it is fully compatible with the instructions from that description. I am happy to tell you that this setup also preserves the buzzer of the display.

The SD card slot on the display:

The SD card slot on the display is not useable (the one on the board still is). There may be the possibility to use it.

Hints (I did not test this): You need to wire all of the J3 wires and LCD:5 goes to EXP2:4 (instead of the Servo of BLTouch) this should be in the firmware LCD_SDSS = 27. You may also need/want to sacrifice the beeper and connect LCD:3 to EXP2:7 that would be the SD_DETECT_PIN = 28 in firmware.

Now for the adapter wiring itself!

It is not hard, just follow it wire by wire. It shows always originating connector:pin from Anet A8 Board > destination connector:pin on the RepRap Display.

Counting is done from the "red marked wire", which is no. 1 of the 10 cables.

The J3 connector is normally not used on your board (besides for flashing firmware with a programmer).

The LCD port is the one which your stock LCD 2004 Controller is plugged into.

The original display and the Anet board are not modified. You can always switch back.

J3 Connector on Anet Board

The connections in () are not really needed and can be omitted (yes there is only one needed with the J3).

J3:1 > -
J3:2 > -
J3:3 > (EXP2:1)
J3:4 > -
J3:5 > (EXP2:2)
J3:6 > (EXP2:6)
J3:7 > EXP2:8
J3:8 > (EXP2:9)
J3:9 > -
J3:10 > -

LCD Connector on Anet Board

LCD:1 > EXP1:9
LCD:2 > EXP1:10
LCD:3 > (Optional for BLTouch/3D-Touch)
LCD:4 > EXP2:3
LCD:5 > EXP1:1
LCD:6 > EXP2:5
LCD:7 > EXP1:3
LCD:8 > EXP1:2
LCD:9 > EXP1:4
LCD:10 > EXP1:5

Modifications in the firmware

Update: I added a commit to the SkyNet3D Development repository which contains the changes as easy to use configuration option (experimental)

Changing the firmware manually can be done by editing the pins_ANET_10.h file to address the right pins for this wiring.

    #elif ENABLED(U8GLIB_ST7920)

        // For RepRap Discount (with Anet Adapter wiring)
        #define SERVO0_PIN        27 // free for BLTouch/3D-Touch
        #define BEEPER_PIN        28
        #define LCD_PINS_RS       30
        #define LCD_PINS_ENABLE   29
        #define LCD_PINS_D4       17

/*

        #define BEEPER_PIN 17

        #define LCD_PINS_RS        27
        #define LCD_PINS_ENABLE    28
        #define LCD_PINS_D4        30
*/
        #define ST7920_DELAY_1 DELAY_0_NOP
        #define ST7920_DELAY_2 DELAY_1_NOP
        #define ST7920_DELAY_3 DELAY_2_NOP

        #ifndef ENCODER_STEPS_PER_MENU_ITEM

To enable this display in the firmware you need to tell Configuration.h to use it:

//#define ANET_KEYPAD_LCD
#define ANET_FULL_GRAPHICS_LCD

Have fun with the cheap controller and a nice and much easier to use printer!

comments.text: You reference the github repository for Skynet3d. What is the difference between the version at github and the version on facebook? The version on github is 1.x something and the version on facebook is 2.3x or something....There is a big version number difference.
comments.author: WombatBA

comments.text: The GitHub version is the original Marlin firmware ported for the Anet hardware. That is basically the 1.1.0 release candidate no. 8 + all current Marlin bug fixes + "the port" + all fixes by the current SkyNet3D maintainer (me). The "SkyNet3D" version 2.3 is the version of the package including the Marlin firmware + all you need to make it work on windows. It usually lags behind the code from the GitHub version until the SkyNet3D package sees a new release. Think of it as "raw" and "cooked". The GitHub version is what Pete uses to cook a new SkyNet3D release. As the releases differ one needs different version numbers for the different products. SkyNet3D is supported on Facebook. I don't do any support for SkyNet3D or Marlin, nor give I any guarantees that the GitHub code is working at a specific time. If you know what you are doing, using the GitHub version is probably ok and you may even help with development. If not, you should stay with the SkyNet3D releases or at least don't shout at me if the GitHub version breaks stuff for you :)
comments.author: WombatBA

description.text:
This is a Christmas village house that I designed to be the same scale as the standard ceramic holiday house and to fit right in under a Christmas tree or in a Christmas scene display. The inside is hollow, so it saves filament and allows you to put lights underneath. I was able to print this model without supports, but there may be some stringing along the eaves of the roof, due to unsupported overhangs.

For best results, print this in natural PLA or some other semi-transparent or translucent filament. If you mask the windows and paint the model, the light from an LED tealight will shine through the windows.

description.text:
Jessen's Orthogonal Icosahedron is a concave 20-sided polyhedra that was discovered by Børge Jessen in 1967. It possess a variety of mathematical properties, such as being scissor congruent to a cube and being a "shaky" or multistable shape. Given that there has not been a ton of work on this particular subject, I figured I would design it in CAD and 3D print it to have a physical version.

YouTube Video: https://youtu.be/9-HnJ9n6F20

I covered my results in the video linked above. I found that the shape can undergo a fascinating transformation when made from a flexible material. When compressed, the shape collapses into an octohedron.

Resolution:

.2mm-.1mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Print with 2 shells and .8mm top/bottom thickness in a flexible material such as NinjaFlex or WillowFlex in order to have a collapsible version of the shape

title: Tippman M4 TDC
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
TEMPORARY NOTE: This project is still in beta stage. It is subject to change. I am testing this design currently and will update as I go. If you use this it may not be perfect etc.

NOTE: This is designed for an advanced user and requires assembly by the form of tapping your own thread with a metric M4 tap. And using a screw for adjustment and pressure on the Nub. If this is not possible there is commercial TDC mods for the Tippmann M4 that might be more appropriate for you.

As any Tippmann M4 user will know the stock hop-up adjustment is by far the weakest part of the gun. Thankfully they gave us a pre cut tube right above the hop unit perfect for a Top Dead Center Mod.

I recommend adding a bit of rubber or eraser to the plastic nub if it is being used on a plain flat hop. This will help prevent rips and damages to the bucking.

So far I have tested this with the stock barrel and bucking with good results.
Aim to test with a flathopped setup and RHopped ZCI Barrel.

Update Log

Released Beta

title: Heater Block Silicone Rubber Sock Mold

description.text:
A mold to make your own silicone rubber sock for the E3D V6/Lite6 heater block. Insulating the heater block keeps the nozzle temperature stable, unaffected by the part cooling fan and other external temperature changes.

Print with 1 wall. Left and right side version included with cutout to allow exit of thermistor / heater cartridge wiring.

Prepare the mold by lining the inside with scotch tape (silicone rubber won't stick to scotch tape). Cut out tape covering the hole for the nozzle and heater cartridge wiring window.

Prepare the heater block. Wrap the heater block with teflon tape (used by plumbers, silicone rubber also won't stick to teflon). Make sure to cover the nozzle as well. Press the teflon on the area around the nozzle to shape it more or less like the nozzle itself.

Fill mold about 2/3 full with high-temperature RTV silicone rubber. Make sure the corners are filled properly.
High-temp RTV silicone rubber is available in auto-parts shops and they come in tubes. Buy the highest temperature rating you can get.

Push the block into the mold until the nozzle cone goes through the hole and nozzle nut hits the bottom of the mold. Make sure the nozzle tip comes out of the hole at the bottom of the mold. Excess silicone rubber will go up the top side of the heater block. Use an oiled spatula to shape the excess silicone rubber on to the top of the block. Let dry for at least 12 hours before removing the mold. You may have to break it open if it gets stuck. Let cure for 24 hours before using.

Make sure to remove teflon tape covering the nozzle tip before using.
Recalibrate PID settings.

Cured siliicone rubber sock can be removed from heater block if necessary.

Kossel Mini

print_settings.Printer:: Type A Machines 2015 Series 1

description.text: I've been away from Thingiverse for quite some years, but I was getting thirsty, so I designed this simple cup to test out printing with translucent filaments

Printer Brand:

Type A Machines

Printer:

Type A Machines 2015 Series 1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

15% or none

Notes:

The inner part of the cup is smooth and curved at the bottom so that if you print with dishwasher safe material, you can actually wash it.

If you print with a 4 perimeters, and 5 bottom/top layers, that should be sufficient to make it water tight, but experimentation is the name of the game.

I used OpenScad
Starting with a simple circular base with 8 sides,
I then used a linear extrude to the height of the cup, with a twist component of 180 degrees. That gives it that faceted look.
Then I subtracted a cylinder with rounded ends from the middle of the twisted circle, and the cup is the result.

description.text:
There are some awesome candy dispensers here on thingiverse. I made this new one to save on filament (this single dispenser uses only .1 kg and the 3x dispenser uses only .22 kg), to be small, and to only dispense a small amount of candy per turn. I am using this at the receptionist desk of my office (to keep away from the open candy jar grossness) and at my house to stop the huge amount of candy given per vend. Further I added threads to the print (which many machines do not seem to have for some reason) that fit a standard mason jar.

I also found that with the other candy dispensers the candy would get jammed or cut off in the tumbler while vending. I used to run a vending machine route as a teen, and remember we had to change out the professional machine's tumblers based on the types of candy/toys it was vending. So, I am designing tumblers specific to the types of candies, and marking the tumblers so they can be easily changed out.

Since these are so small, I designed the tumblers with a slot to insert a quarter in the front to use as a handle. While I originally intended to glue the quarters in, I found if you fold a small amount of tape over the part of the quarter that goes in, it will hold firmly in place.

The first tumbler is designed to work with Lemon Heads. It also works with jelly bellies, but not very well. It will consistently dispense two Lemon Heads without getting stuck (though the random malformed candy may cause problems I have not seen it yet).

The Jelly Belly Tumbler is done and working well. Because jelly beans are not round the tumbler may stick, but I added some play and changed the recess size so that you will get 3 beans out of it. If it does catch just wiggle the tumbler back and forth and it should free up easily.

Red Hots tumbler is done. I put a pocket on each side, so a 1/2 turn will drop them, and they come out quick.

I will continue adding tumblers for different candies. Let me know if you have any requests

Since there are unsupported flat part on the interior part of these dispensers, there will likely be some messed up part of the print, but it is on the underside where you cannot see it. I accepted this as a trade off for the savings on filament.

UPDATES:
-Dispensers v1.1: Removed lip to slow down candy pieces and slanted lip to make pieces easier to remove.
-Dispensers v1.2: Extended feed ramp so candies come out further when dispensed.
-Dispensers "thick": I had some cracking around the jar threads at the top of the dispenser, so I made a version that has a bit thicker rim (I also turned up the heat on my extruder a bit). It sticks out past the edges a bit, so I am only adding it as an alternate version not replacing the main. Let me know what you think of it, and maybe I will spend some more time reworking it to make it stronger.
-Thanks to a comment, I found a mistake in the Thick Version of the dispensers. It should be fixed now.

description.text:
FR632 Tri Pod Mount

42mm quick release

After using this excellent razor stand for a while I realized what I was missing was a way to tell how many times I'd used each razor blade. I swap out the blade after a few uses but sometimes I forget how many uses it's been through. Did I shave yesterday? Did I swap that blade out before or after I shaved? Rather than have a dull blade that I cut myself on I'd rather keep track.

So I combined the equally amazing life tracker counter rings with the razor holder to produce a razor holder that can keep track of this for me.

Just a quick stand I made for some test tubes...

Note: The tubes that I made this stand for have a 1.25" diameter. Numbers should be adjusted if you are using smaller tubes.
Any color of filament. Can be wood-based, but plastic is recommended

print_settings.Notes:: I wanted these to be as smooth as possible so I printed these slow (@30mm/s) and at high res (.1mm). I also printed them @35% infill, which is pretty much solid for something this size. Lay flat when you print for best results.

description.text:
I have large wrists and so I really liked pharao's wristband extension for my Garmin Forerunner 235. I really do not like silicon bands though, so after looking and not finding any, I decided to make an adapter so I could use a nylon watchband instead.

I have printed and use, the 22mm watchband adapter, but I figured I would design some more for anyone that may want a different size (if you print in another size and it does not work, or want a size not here, ping me). I am also working out an adapter to use as a paracord wristband, and will upload when done.

After printing, I have had the best success, using small drill bits to clean out the holes for the garmin band pin (~5/64) and the watch snap pin (~1/16). You do not need to make the holes bigger, it was just helpful to perfectly round the holes.

remixed_from.title: Dual 60mm fan side mount for the XYZ Da Vinci printer

title: Dual 60mm side fan with charcoal filter

description.text:
This remix was done to extend the fan mount allowing for the inclusion of an activated charcoal sponge for filtration.

The remix includes an extended box section and the new grid. This grid is a press fit into the box and is a separator between the charcoal sponge and the fans.

During assembly ensure that your fans are mounts to suck air from the case (through the filter) and eject it. Once the fans are mounted and wired push the grid section in as far as it can go, it will rest above the fans. Aquire some activated charcoal sponge, mine can from the local pet store and is used in fish tanks. Cut the sponge to fit.

NOTE:

  • If your sponge needs to be held into place you can print a second grid to hold this down.
  • I used low speed, quiet, high flow fans from GELID. I have used these fans a lot and they are great quality and long lasting. The wiring for these is all black so included is a reference image to help wiring the fans to 12v.
  • I sourced my 12v (200mA) from the printers main PSU (along with the 12v for my E3D hotend fan). A reference image is included, however you can use any 12v source that can provide 200mA

author: richardtracy

description.text:
I made this for my Harbor Freight 0.53 cu. ft. Wall Safe Item # 62983. Also known under the Union Safe brand, possibly others.

In the dark you can not see the buttons to enter your code. So a made one with a little LED a switch and a 2032 button cell battery. It fits in place of the manual key cover.

Also worth mentioning, this safe has a really loud annoying beep when entering your code. I opened the inside cover on mine and cut out the piezo speaker element to make it silent. I keep my gun in here and if I have an intruder I do not want the sound to alert them.

title: Improved and more gentle atomic pull method of nozzle cleaning

description.text:
I can take no credit for this and the method is described here.

https://www.uantwerpen.be/images/uantwerpen/container11343/files/improved_atomic_method_v20160713.pdf

The basic approach is to heat the filament, extrude a little, and then back off to reduce amount of filament in the PTFE tube between the extruder gear and hot end. You then leave it to cool down very thoroughly before heating such that the filament just melts while "doing the twizzle".

I've done this successfully many times on a Wanhao Duplicator I3 Plus whereas I failed every time at the traditional atomic pull.

Read the pdf and also the comments in the gcode. TwizzleS1 does the heat, extrude, back off, and cool, so you just run it and walk away for 30-40 minutes. You then run S2 while twizzling, and manually raise extruder temperature a little if required.

Let me know how you get on.

(Ignore the dummy file. Thingiverse doesn't like Things without Things.)

print_settings.Notes:: I have used PLA, however plastic will not survive crashes as well as an expensive carbon fibre frame. I've used 30% infill which seems adequate for me although different pilots will have different preferences.

description.text:
This is a quadcopter frame suitable for 5 inch props. I created it to replace a damaged frame on an older quadcopter. The unibody baseplate is designed to fit on a 200x200mm printer.

edit. I've added a 20 degree action cam mount which is suitable for Mobius or Session form factor action cams. It has a 20 degree overhang and may require supports on some printers.

Printer:

Cocoon Create

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I have used PLA, however plastic will not survive crashes as well as an expensive carbon fibre frame. I've used 30% infill which seems adequate for me although different pilots will have different preferences.

I have included two baseplates. The 1806 plate suits smaller motors with 2mm screws with hole spacing of up to 16mm. The 2205 plate is for larger motors with 3mm screws and hole spacing of 16-19mm.

I used 37mm standoffs from hobbyking. There is a 14.8mm gap between the front two standoffs which is enough room for a standard Runcam swift camera or similar. Cameras with larger lenses may not fit. Standoffs that are too short may create clearance issues for the propellers, and standoffs that are too thick may not leave enough room for the camera.

https://hobbyking.com/en_us/hobbyking-m3-x-37mm-aluminum-standoff-for-color-250-blade-multirotors-10pc.html

I've included an alternate top plate with a mount for a board camera, although it could probably do with a little work.

title: Modified 12mm bearing holders (TAZ6 X-axis) for RJ4JP-01-12
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A replacement set of the TAZ 6 12mm bearing holders for the X-axis. Made to fit the JP IGUS bearings, that have a smaller outer diameter.

The originals are using RJMP-01-12 IGUS bearings. These bearing holders are designed to fit the RJ4JP-01-12 IGUS bearings (Japanese size): http://www.igus.de/wpck/17732/drylin_R_RJ4JP?C=DE&L=de

The original files are found here:
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/6.01/production_parts/printed_parts/12mm_double_bearing_holder/
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/6.01/production_parts/printed_parts/12mm_single_bearing_holder/

LulzBot is a registered trademark of Aleph Objects, Inc.

Make a perfect fit

It took me 4 revisions to make the single bearing fit and slide properly. And for the double, it took two prints - The fit has to be perfect, and this is completely dependent on the accuracy and settings of your printer!

Advise to:

  1. Print the single bearing - If it fits, great, skip straight to step 3.
  2. Adjust the Extrusion Multiplier in your slicer and print again until the fit is right.
  3. Print the double bearing - If needed follow step 2 to make a perfect fit.
Used the original as the reference. Then created my own FreeCAD drawings from scratch.

description.text:
I love the Adafruit hook-up wire spool set ( https://www.adafruit.com/products/1311 ), but the cardboard box it comes in takes up too much of my limited workbench space.
I've thrown together this hanging spool holder and it's completely solved the problem for my particular situation.

Note that I'm using a cheap workbench I bought from Bunnings Australia:
https://www.bunnings.com.au/pinnacle-compact-garage-workbench_p2760256
This is designed to fit that, but I've included my original FreeCAD file if you want to make changes.

The included wooden rod was slightly too large to fit into the holes (despite my careful measuring), so I ended up rounding the edges with a file about 5mm from each end. I'd recommend doing a little bit at a time until it just fits snugly.

title: Overhangtest
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Remix of the Make Overhang performance test.
I did not like, that the steps between the angles were so big, as no 3D-Printer should strugle at 30° and most printers don't get 70° printet well, if the perimeters are not specially optimized just for overhang.

Normaly the turning point is somewere between 50° to 70° so I made 5° steps in between.

Should allow you to analyze exactly what your printer ist capable of.

Printer:

fullmetal P3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

As it's easier to scale things down, I made it a bit bigger.

For normal testing you can scale it to 60%.

Printing it in full size will eliminate some sideeffects and give you much more significant results.

A simple case for small arduino boards. Can be adapted with customizer. The default parameter (and includes stl files) are for a pro micro board (without pin connectors. With pin connectors it would not fit into the slots of the case. But you can adopt all sizes with customizer or directly in the open scad file).
I am using it for an R/C transmitter to USB joystick interface, which I am using for picasim, a free r/c simulator.
The board slides into the case and the cap slides into the case, too. Therefore you do not need screws to close the case. If the gap is aligned to your printer the cap holds without glue.

title: Mounting plate for E3D_v6, fits original TAZ 6
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A mounting plate that fits the original TAZ 6 extruder. The difference from the original, is that the original is make for Hexagon hotend which has a higher collar and a lower neck than the E3D v6.
This mounting plate takes account for that by having a lower allround height, and a support for the collar.

The original file is found here:
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/accessories/hot_ends/Hexagon_v2_Hot_End/lulzbot_edition_hexagon_hotend-0.5mm/

LulzBot is a registered trademark of Aleph Objects, Inc.
Used the original as the reference. Then created my own FreeCAD drawings from scratch.

comments.text: A buddy of mine has a Taz6, while I have a pair of Prusa MK2 machines.  We're going to try your mount, as we'd like to standardize to the 1.75mm filament.  Found where people were using 1.75mm successfully online, but we have yet to be able to mimic their success with his Taz6.  We have the E3D V6 hot end ready to go, just need to print this and see how it all installs.
comments.author: wjbirm

comments.text: Great! I wish you luck and hope it works out. Let me know after you have tested it.
comments.author: wjbirm

comments.text: It works, but the issue we're having, in trying to migrate to 1.75mm, is that the filament is easily stripped out.  We have downsized the nozzle from 0.5mm (Taz6 stock) to 0.4mm.  Have you encountered this issue as well?
comments.author: feedrate

comments.text: I see. Never have as I'm quite happy about 3mm filament myself.
comments.author: wjbirm

comments.text: Oh yeah.  We've tried the Hexagon head, with and without PTFE tubing, and have now changed over to the E3D V6 head with your adapter.  We thought, since the Hexagon head was designed for 3mm, that maybe the excessive space in the head was causing us issues.  That was the whole reason to change to the E3D V6 head.  But, after having done so, we're still having issues with the 1.75mm filament stripping out easily.  It'll start the print just fine, but then after a little while, you can see under extrusion starting, and progressively getting worse, sometimes better, than extrusion just stops.  We've tried light/medium/heavy tension on the hobbed bolt, but nothing seems to make any difference.
comments.author: feedrate

comments.text:
Alright, then you would need a modified extruder head/body to account for the offset there's between the hobbed gear and filament guide, and simply to guide it straight down into the extruder. Could also need a hobbed gear with a 1.75 diameter simply for a better grip, but for initial testing the old one for 3mm should work in most cases.
But with that (and changing FW settings naturally) you should be golden!
comments.author: wjbirm

title: Knob for M8 bolt or nut

description.text:
A knob for either a M8 Bolt or a Nut.
The nut or bolt is snug but easy to press into place

Added a tight fit version where you probably have to print it in at least 50% infill and press it in place in a vise. Or you can heat the bolt up with a soldering iron and press it in place with the tip of the soldering iron. The nut/bolt well is a bit tapered to make it easier to press into place.

If you need it to be really sturdy, print with 3.2mm Shell thickness (with a 0.4mm nozzle) then the infill can be 20%

Printer:

Creality Cr-10s

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Best print result if printed upside down e.g. top side against the plate

author: tomarppe

description.text:
This a great little puzzle by Mineyuki Uyematsu that I saw on Puzzle Will Be Played last week.
http://puzzlewillbeplayed.com/444/CubeLibre/
It's another great example of a printable puzzle that requires no support on RepRap printers.
These 10 puzzle pieces can make both an 8x8 square and a 4x4x4 cube.
I designed a special box in Tinkercad that allows the puzzler to play both games. https://tinkercad.com/things/8Jzfov4OYUA

Print one complete set of ten puzzle pieces (there are 4 of piece A, 4 of piece B and 2 of piece C).
Neither problem is easy; there is only one solution in each case.
Optionally, print the box/tray to keep them in and demonstrate the solution. The pyramid-shaped box has a cube-shaped hole in the top and a square tray on the bottom.
The box can be printed without support if your reprap prints bridges nicely. If not, you might prefer to try printing the box with support turned on.
A really lovely double challenge.

comments.text: Solution here: https://youtu.be/bsjPN4f-CYI

title: Caliper jaws extensions / Extensions pour becs de pied à coulisse
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Important

Il existe beaucoup de modèles de pieds à coulisse et malheureusement, chacun possède des dimensions de becs différentes.
Ces extensions sont prévues pour se monter sur ce pied à coulisse : http://www.banggood.com/fr/Mitutoyo-6inch-0-150mm0_01mm-Digital-Caliper-Stainless-Steel-Electronic-Vernier-Calipers-p-1012111.html?rmmds=myorder
Désolé pour ceux qui possèdent un autre modèle.

Descriptif

Avec ces extensions, il est possible de pouvoir mesurer jusqu'à 34,5 cm avec un pied à coulisse qui à l'origine ne peut mesurer que 15 cm.
Les 2 extensions droites (+32 mm par rapport à l'origine) permettent de pouvoir mesurer des tubes de plus gros diamètre ou d'atteindre des endroits difficilement accessibles.

A noter

Imprimer un accessoire pour un appareil précis à 0.01mm sans perdre de précision est pratiquement impossible avec nos petites imprimantes. Ne perdez pas de vue quand utilisant ces extensions (surtout avec les grandes) vous allez perdre un peu de précision, mais cela reste acceptable.
Afin de perdre le moins de précision possible, chaque extension doit être parfaitement ajustée et pouvoir se monter en forçant très légèrement de façon à éliminer le moindre jeu.
Les aimants peuvent être collés à la "super glue".

liste des courses
  • 4 aimants Rare-earth Neodymium de 8 × 1.5 mm comme ceux-là : https://www.fasttech.com/p/1860504


(sorry for my poor English)

Important

There exists much of models of calipers and unfortunately, each one has different dimensions of jaws.
These extensions are designed to be assembled on this caliper : http://www.banggood.com/fr/Mitutoyo-6inch-0-150mm0_01mm-Digital-Caliper-Stainless-Steel-Electronic-Vernier-Calipers-p-1012111.html?rmmds=myorder
Sorry for those which have another model.

Description

With these extensions, it is possible to measure up to 34.5 cm with a caliper which in the beginning can measure only 15 cm.
With 2 straight extensions (+32 mm compared to the origin) make it possible to measure bigger tubes or to reach difficult to reach places.

To note

To print an accessory for a precise device with 0.01mm without losing precision is practically impossible with our small printers. Do not lose sight of the fact when using these extensions (especially with the larger ones) you will lose a little precision, but that remains acceptable.
In order to lose less possible precision, each extension must be perfectly adjusted and be able to be very slightly assembled while forcing in order to eliminate the gap.
The magnets can be stuck to the “super glue”.

BOM
  • 4 magnets rare-earth Neodymium 8 × 1.5 mm like these : https://www.fasttech.com/p/1860504

title: 3D printed Back Load Horn Bluetooth Speaker-V2

description.text:
This is a 3D printed back load horn bluetooth speaker project.
You will need two 1inch 3W full range speakers and bluetooth amp.
An 1 inch speaker is very small but it will make very big sound because it is mounted on back load horn body.
Especially it's sound is so natural because it use only one speaker per channel so it is not needed coils and capacitors network system which will reduce sound quality.
Usually back load horn speaker system is very expensive.
But now, enjoy extreme sound quality with cheap price using your 3D printer!

description.text:
Materials needed:

1) Kitchen Timer - Got an super-cheap Egg Shaped timer.

The reduction ratio is 4:1, so in 1h of time lapse, the came will rotate ~ 90 degrees (take this in mind not focusing the object in the start of the time lapse).

Instructions: Pull the top part of the eggtimer apart. Release the bottom screw and mount the internal mechanism in the base section. Secure with the screw.

Homopolar motor is a simple motor.

Demonstrating it sometimes a bit tricky especially for younger kids, the wire keep falling off from top of battery.
We created a sleeve to be placed on top of AA battery to keep the wire from falling, hence continuous fun and rotation :)
You can print the optional "Motor" text.

Additional parts : wire (~22 cm), Strong magnets (3-4 pcs) , AA battery.

From Wikipedia:
The homopolar motor is driven by the Lorentz force. A conductor with a current flowing through it when placed in a magnetic field which is perpendicular to the current feels a force in the direction perpendicular to both the magnetic field and the current. This force provides a torque around the axis of rotation. Because the axis of rotation is parallel to the magnetic field, and the opposing magnetic fields do not change polarity, no commutation is required for the conductor to keep turning. This simplicity is most readily achieved with single turn designs, which makes homopolar motors unsuitable for most practical applications

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.30mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

Straightforward printing, no special setting
Total print time around 15 minutes for both objects.

Print battery sleeve's small side on the bottom therefore eliminating support.
For text, just lay it flat with wire groove facing up.
